title.narrative: SCB phase II Institutional Capacity Building GeoStat
SCB phase II Institutional Capacity Building GeoStat

description.narrative:
Statistics Sweden (SCB) and National Statistics Office of Georgia (GeoStat) has applied to Sida for funding of 13, 492 000 SEK to carry out the "Institutional Capacity Building Project of the National Statistics Office of Georgia, " during the period 2015-2018.
The intervention aims that GeoStat improves its institutional capacity to produce quality statistics in line with EU and international standards; focusing on Management and Human Resources development, the Statistical Methods, National Accounts, Price Statistics, Business Statistics, Social Statistics, Gender Statistics, Environment Statistics. Statistics Sweden will implement the intervention together with National Statistics Office of Georgia.
The total budget of the intervention amounts to 13 492 000 SEK.

Statistiska centralbyrån (SCB) och Geostat har ansökt om bidrag på 13 492 000 SEK för genomförandet av projektet “Institutional Capacity Building Project of the National Statistics Office of Georgia” under 2015-2018.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra Geostats institutionella kapacitet och producera kvalitésäker statistik i enlighet med EU standarder. Fokus kommer att vara på förvaltning och utveckling av personalresurser, statistikmetoder, nationalräkenskaper, prisstatistik, företagsstatistik, samhällsstatistik, jämställdhetsstatistik och miljöstatistik. Statistiska Centralbyrån kommer att implementera insatsen tillsammans med den georgiske partnern GeoStat. Insatsens totala budget är 13 492 000 SEK.
The development intervention's intended outcome is that GeoStat has improved its institutional capacity to produce quality statistics in line with EU and international standards.

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The contribution activities of the cooperation project between Statistics Sweden and Geostat lasted for the period from 1 July 2015 to 30 June 2018 and volume of the support by the end of the project made 12 254 795 SEK. The project overall objective was for Geostat to improve its institutional capacity to produce quality statistics in line with EU and international standards The project focused on seven components, namely:? Price Statistics? National Accounts? Social Statistics? Business Statistics? Statistical Methods? Management? Environmental Statistics The project has delivered results in line with the overall objective and also, in general, in line with expected outcomes. Some of the most important achievements are briefly described below. The cooperation within the area of price statistics has been successful with creation of several new price indices. An Import Price Index has been developed and the Producer Price Index (PPI) has been divided into a Domestic PPI and an Export Price Index. Furthermore, a Construction Cost Index (CCI) has been developed from scratch. All these indices constitute valuable input to the National Accounts and can also be used for business cycle analysis. The support on the business statistics survey has been on a very technical level, with involvement of the sampling expert from Geostat and the subject matter staff who after in depth discussions agreed on the methodology used for sampling and estimation. Based on increased quality of the sample frame Geostat has been able to improve the sampling methods. Sample sizes have increased from 9 000 to 11 500 in the quarterly survey and from 12 500 to 15 500 in the annual survey, leading to decreased margin of errors (i.e. uncertainty) for the estimations. The quality has increased further due to the use of fewer strata in the sampling. Social statistics was covered by two statistical aspects within the project - tourism statistics and gender statistics. As about tourism statistics Geostat developed by 2017 domestic and inbound tourism surveys and in the same year it was decided to complement the existing surveys with an outbound tourism survey, to cover the travels abroad conducted by Georgians. A preparatory work was initiated, a work plan was created, and a pilot survey was planned to be conducted in September/October 2018. The first publication would take place in early 2019. Thus compared to the start of the project, there is now more tourism statistics available and the reliability has been increased due to updates in the questionnaires and improved methodology for sampling and estimation. From early 2019, the availability will increase further, with the publishing of results from the outbound tourism survey. Together with the domestic and outbound surveys, this will mean that Georgia will fulfil the EU regulation for tourism statistics. Gender as the cross cutting important matter was well covered by the project. As a result the availability of user-friendly gender statistics has increased significantly and users can get the gender statistics from well functioning Geostat web-page. In addition to tangible results, the engagement of the staff working on gender statistics has increased, with several initiatives for gender related activities. Two gender seminars have been arranged, with participants from the parliament, several ministries, NGOs and media. Partly due to the increased availability of statistics, gender related issues have been more highlighted in Georgia and the awareness of Geostat’s work on gender statistics has increased. The knowledge of statistical methodology has been more spread out within Geostat. More than 40 staff members from Geostat and other government agencies have participated in so called Statistics in Action (STAC)- two weeks basic methodology courses that give the participants a good understanding of what a survey is and how it can be conducted. More importantly two Geostat staff members have been trained to become future STAC teachers. Geostat now has the capacity to arrange these courses themselves For the improvement of the Geostat management the establishment of a Methodology and Quality Management subdivision has played an important role. This subdivision has the responsibility to ensure that Geostat have updated documentation and are following Geostat’s quality guidelines. It also has the responsibility for the indicators for the Sustainable Development Goals. The knowledge among the staff is very high and the subdivision is able to support the rest of the organization on quality issues.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
